data.title: Thomas Lane (1689-aft.1747)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Thomas Lane born 1689 St Stephen's Parish, Northumberland, Virginia died 1747 Hanover County, Virginia including ancestors + descendants + 2 photos + 6 genealogist comments + Y-chromosome DNA + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 8 Feb 2023 | Created 8 Oct 2012

This page has been accessed 1,986 times.

Contents

1 Biography

2 Records Lost

2.1 Research Notes

3 Sources

Biography

Thomas Lane was born 16 Mar 1688/89 in Virginia to James Lane and his first wife, name unknown, and passed away after 1742. [1]

Birth Listed in St. Stephen's Parish of Northumberland:

James Lane, son of James born Jany 17, 1686

Thomas Lane, son of DO born Mar 16, 1688

His mother died before 1692, and his father remarried to Martha Tidwell.

Thomas Lane b. 1683; had 100 ac New Kent, VA by 1704. It is likely that he had property in Hanover in 1719. He was on vestry of St Paul's Church in 1719. Who he married is not known, but the following are his likely issue: (son) Lane, Edward Lane b. 1705; Thomas Lane b. 1715; Daniel Lane b. 1725.[2]

21 Feb 1704 A George Eskridge in Northumberland Co. VA granted 2,950a for transporting about 30 people, including a Thomas Lane. (The following year Eskridge was granted 1050a for transporting several including a Mary Lane.

18 Jun 1712 Northumberland Co. Court Record: John Thomas, Court order that a road be laid out through his land for Tho. Laine. 18 Jun 1712

25 Aug 1714 Lancaster Co. VA, DB11, pg2: Richard Wood of Lancaster County VA sells land to Thomas Lane of Northumberland Co. For Richard's love and affection and for one gray mare branded with an R on the right buttock ... land beginning at a white chestnut in Richard Woods ... James Black's line ...the main branch of Marrati..Creek ... Daniel MacCarty's line ... Wicomico River .. to the beginning. Wits: George Merdock(?), Richd. Welch, Daniel Coavaill(?)

20 Feb 1719 Thomas Lane granted the right to purchase 600a for 3 pounds. The land was on the north side of Little River at the North Anna and Pamunkey, adjoining John Kimbrow and Edward Garland. New Kent County VA.

29 Jul 1719 Need explicit data on the following:

'WESTMORELAND COUNTY, VIRGINIA ORDER BOOK: 1718-1721 [Antient Press]; Page 371 At a Court held for the said County the 29th day of July 1719. GEORGE TURBERVILE, Gent. presented into Court an Inquisition by him taken on the body of THOMAS LANE and one other taken on the body of JANE MORRISS both which were ordered to'

This entry could be the link for this Thomas and his father James to Thomas Lane of Northumberland (our current subject's possible grandfather). As of yet, there is no hard evidence linking this Thomas to James, and no hard evidence linking James to the older Thomas.

8 Oct 1719 Thomas Lane's land processioned into a precinct.

8 Feb 1720 Lancaster Co. VA Book 11, page 184: Thomas Lane of St. Mary's White Chappell in Lancaster County VA to Owen Kelly of same. Sd. Thomas Lane for in consideration of 1070lbs of Tobacco, one pair of spoons & ladel, ...five yards of Kerley & buttons, Mohair to trim, to him the sd Thomas Lane by Owen Kelly, 35a of land in Lancaster, part of 420a granted to Richd White & George Vincent in 4 Apr 1671. Beginning at a White Chestnut in Thomas Lane's ... James Blackaby's ... Morratico Cr. ... Capt. Danl(?) McCarty's ...Wicomico River... Yearly rent ... Wits: Wm Payne, Thomas Chattin, Peter Carter. 8 Mar 1720 Richard Wood atty for Patience wife of Thomas, relinquished her dower...(beloved friend and father Richard Wood). Wits: Peter Rover, Jane Wood.

9 Jul 1724 Thomas Lane granted 472a in the southern section of Hanover adj. Capt. Nathaniel West's Mill Creek Tract and Charles Chiswell.

1739 Thomas Lane and sons William and Daniel are documented in the Cedar Creek Quaker meeting house in Hanover County VA.

1742 Louisa County created. It's clear that Thomas was granted more lands in Hanover that fell into Louisa when it was created. Those records recorded in Hanover were likely lost in the fire.

1747 Death. In a 1746 deed in Louisa his son Thomas Lane was referred to as Jr. which likely meant this man was still alive. Therefore, our current subject died in 1747 or later. No record available. Many lands were clearly inherited by his children in Louisa (and sold later) but the inheritance records were lost.

Records Lost

1862 Hanover County Historical Society Quote: The Battle of Hanover Courthouse, on May 27, 1862, brought heavy skirmishing through the Courthouse area, and when Union forces returned at the end of May 1864, they imprisoned Hanover County's Clerk of Court.

The county's court records were shortly thereafter boxed up and moved to Richmond for "safekeeping," which proved to be a poor decision indeed when much of Richmond was burned to the ground in April of 1865 by the retreating Confederacy. Hanover is considered a Burned Record County, as most of its pre-Civil War court records were lost in the blaze.

Research Notes

Apparently many records for Hanover County have been destroyed.

English Duplicates of Lost VA Records of Quit Rents of 1704 include a Thomas Lane of New Kent, VA (p. 167) and Thomas Lane and Thomas Lane, Jr of Surry (p. 268). New Kent is adjacent to Hanover and 70 miles away from Surry/Sussex.

Sources

↑ "James Lane", p.7 in N. Quackenbush, "Some Northern Neck Lanes", in Virginia Genealogical Society Quarterly, Vol 24, Number 4. Available here at Ancestry.com

↑ Layne, Floyd Benjamin. Layne-Lain-Lane Genealogy: Chapt C: Descendants of Thomas Lane-Layne of Hanover County, Virginia, p. 121.
